text:
Secretary of State Anthony Blinken is 
visiting several Arab states today to

discuss the current conflict 
between Israel and Hamas.

And Steve Scalis is dropping out 
of the race to be House Speaker.

Good morning. I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Israel is telling Palestinians in northern Gaza to 
leave immediately and go to the southern part of

the enclave. They've been given 24 hours to 
do so. It's feared that an Israeli military

ground assault will soon begin. Hamas leaders 
have told Palestinians not to go anywhere.

U.N. officials and other human rights groups are 
urgently warning that a million Palestinians are

under the Israeli warning, and it's impossible 
to move that many people in so short a time.

Separately, Hamas leaders are claiming 
that Israeli airstrikes have killed 13
Israeli and foreign hostages. The claim has not

been confirmed. Hamas has abducted 
scores of people out of Israel.

Secretary of State Anthony Blinken 
is making a swing through several

Arab states today to discuss the 
conflict. NPR's Michelle Kellerman

reports he wants the leaders to 
urge Hamas to free the hostages:

"Secretary Blinken started his day with 
a closed-door meeting with Jordan's King

Abdullah followed by talks with the Palestinian 
Authority President, who has a residence in

Amman. The State Department says Blinken 
discussed the 'horrific' Hamas terrorist

attacks on Israel and the efforts to secure 
the release of all hostages and prevent the

conflict from widening. That's a message he's 
also bringing to Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia,

the United Arab Emirates and Egypt. At that last 
stop, Blinken will also discuss efforts to open up

a humanitarian corridor out of Gaza, especially 
for Palestinian Americans trapped there.
"Michelle Kellerman, NPR News, Amman."

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin 
arrived in Tel Aviv a few hours

ago. He's meeting with Israeli leaders to 
discuss U.S. security assistance to Israel.

Republican Congressman Steve Scalise is 
quitting the race to become the next Speaker

of the House. NPR's Giles Snyder reports he 
didn't have the votes from other Republicans:

"Congressman Scalise spoke 
to reporters after emerging

from a closed-door meeting with 
his House Republican colleagues,

saying he is withdrawing after they failed 
to come together around his nomination:

'Clearly, not everybody is there, and there's 
still schisms that have to get resolved.'

"The House has been without of Speaker 
since the ouster of Kevin McCarthy,

leaving the chamber unable to take action on 
the government spending bills needed to avoid

a shutdown in November and facing pressure 
to support Israel in the war with Hamas.
"Giles Snider, NPR News."

Philadelphia police say one officer has 
been killed and another wounded after they

tried to interrupt thieves breaking into 
a car at the airport. Interim Philadelphia

Police Commissioner John Stanford says 
they're looking for the assailants:

"There are multiple suspects that were 
involved in this situation, so, um,

still trying to get some additional information 
on those other individuals that were involved so

we can get that information out 
as quickly as we possibly can."

Philadelphia authorities say another 
person was taken to the hospital,
rather, hospital separately and died.
This is NPR.
